title: Two prisoners were captured ALIVE during al-Baghdadi strike, US military's top officer confirms
text:
Two prisoners were captured alive in the US strike that killed ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Mark Milley announced that two people had been taken into custody and are being held at a secure location during a press briefing alongside Defense Secretary Mark Esper on Monday at the Pentagon.

Milley did not reveal any additional information about the detainees or how they were connected to al-Baghdadi, but they are believed to have surrendered during the raid.

Two prisoners were captured alive in the US strike that killed ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Mark Milley (pictured) announced on Monday

Al-Baghdadi (pictured) detonated his suicide vest as special ops officers with the US Army Delta Force and Rangers closed in on his Syrian compound on Saturday

Between 50 and 70 members of the US Army Delta Force and Rangers closed in on al-Baghdadi's hideout in Syria's Idlib province on Saturday evening, prompting the ISIS mastermind to flee into a dead-end underground tunnel where he detonated his suicide vest, killing himself and his three children.

Milley could not confirm President Donald Trump's description of al-Baghdadi as 'whimpering and crying' in his final moments.

The general said he suspected Trump got that information 'directly to the unit members'.

Al-Baghdadi's remains were taken to a secure facility to confirm his identity with forensic DNA testing, Milley said.

'The disposal of his remains has been done, is complete and was handled appropriately,' he added.

Milley would not confirm reports that al-Baghdadi was buried at sea, as was top Al-Qaeda terrorist Osama bin Laden after he was killed by US forces in a similar helicopter raid in Pakistan in 2011.

General Milley (right) and Defense Secretary Mark Esper (left) held a news conference about the strike on Monday at the Pentagon

Officials have not disclosed the total number killed in the firefight, but President Trump said the casualties outnumbered the captured.

Two of al-Baghdadi's 'wives', both wearing suicide vests which thankfully did not detonate, were killed, along with a large number of the leader's 'fighters and companions'.

US troops reportedly helped get 11 children out of the compound alive.

Milley said the soldiers also gathered a cache of documents which could provide vital intelligence about the Islamic State's origins and future plans.

The general added that there were photos and videos of al-Baghdadi's final moments, which could be released at a later date once they are vetted and declassified.

He declined to provide the name of the K-9 who was injured in the firefight. No other US military members were injured.

Officials have not disclosed the total number killed in the firefight, but President Trump said the casualties outnumbered the captured

While al-Baghdadi's death has deprived IS of its 'inspirational leader,' the security situation in Syria 'remains complex', Defense Secretary Esper told reporters.

He added that US troops were in position to retain control of key oil fields in northeast Syria.

American forces will remain positioned in the strategic area 'to deny ISIS access to those vital resources', and 'overwhelming military force' will be used against any group that threatens their safety, Esper added.

Al-Baghdadi's death will not rid the world of terrorism or end Syria's ongoing conflict, but it sends 'a message to those who would question America's resolve', he said.

'The United States, more than any other nation in the world, possesses the power, and the will, to hunt to the ends of the Earth those who wish to bring harm upon the American people.'
description: Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Mark Milley announced that two men had been taken prisoner and are being held at a secure location during a Monday briefing at the Pentagon.
